Observation Details: I was at the end of Eide Road photographing its continuing Snow Bunting when this Prairie Falcon decided it felt like flying in and landing directly behind me. It flew off after a minute (probably didn't realize there were several people right in front of it watching a bunting when it landed). I initially assumed it was a Peregrine, but when it came in for its landing, I made out the dark armpits and my heart skipped a beat. This bird was seen by several birders, photo attached.

Extremely rare in MI. Continuing at the house where Vikki and cliff had it yesterday evening. First seen (42.8329871, -82.7741638) then flew to hillock here (42.8309657, -82.7802581) and quickly disappeared to south. Then not seen for a couple hours but reappeared on ground here (42.8403613, -82.8230135) then flew west to tall steel electrical tower here (42.8386551, -82.8314199), then south a tower tk here (42.8356476, -82.8313522. Photos show no evidence of jesses or captivity.
best friends forever

Locality: Bosque del Apache NWR--Visitor Center (do not use for whole refuge)
Observation Details: Continuing, as found a couple hours ago by Gary Froehlich. Originally seen just East of the Visitor Center building, on the East side of Hwy. 1. It spent all of its time walking around on the ground, sticking mostly to thick clumps of willows. Occasionally, it would come out into the open. Over the course of about half an hour, it wandered North, then disappeared into some thick willows off to the East. Long-legged raptor with a brown body, white neck and face, and dark cap. Characteristic bill with a pink base and blue-gray tip. Photos.

****very rare, juv, only a handful of records in NV (though one in the state right now), and this is narrowly the northernmost eBird record in the western US. One of the first birds I saw as I arrived, briefly soaring above the trees, I was able to track it down and get pics. It was hunting around the area, moving N and S quite a bit, but I didn’t see it again after about 10am, so it may have departed.

2 adults, 1 juvenile and a first-summer bird all in the air at once. Later saw the first-summer bird bring a prey item to a perch on a telephone wire and feed it to the juvenile. Also saw (and photographed) one of the adults carrying a prey item, but unclear whether it fed the juvenile or not. The prey in the bill of the adult looks like a large yellow grasshopper.
Parents feeding a steady stream of cicadas to juvenile.

Appeared out of nowhere and scared away a flock of least sandpipers peacefully drinking at the pond's edge.  Got great looks on this bird in flight showing its sharp-shinned hawk features:  notched tail, wrist held forward in flight, and small head that barely extend past wrists.  This is an adult bird with the "hooded" appearance of Sharp-shinned, with both crown and back of the neck being dark.

Observation Details: Continuing bird first found by Matt Beatty. I arrived around 1100CDT and the bird was visible above the shooting range. It stayed in the area and visible the entire time I was present until 1215. Medium sized rafter with white under parts and dark backside. It had a deeply Forked tail. It caught several insects throughout the time I was observing it and eating them on the wing. Never landed while I was present.

Locality: FL, Punta Gorda, River Ranch CT

Observation Details: This bird was reported without many details to Maine Audubon in the past day or so. Doug Hitchcox and Fyn Kynd followed up on this report and amazingly found the bird this morning. I arrived in the early afternoon and saw the bird after a brief scan at the intersection of King Street and The Ln. The bird was to the south-southwest over the trees along the Dennys River. It dropped out of sight; so I looked along Route 86 to the west. Shortly after crossing the Dennys River, I spotted the bird over the trees at the edge of a field and bordering the river.  This is one of those birds that is instantly recognizable by shape and pattern--an elegant long-winged raptor with a deeply forked tail. The upperparts and tail were blackish; the underparts, including entire head, were snowy white. In good light, I could see a darker, blackish bar across the leading portion of the upper wing. The secondaries seemed shiny and glossed with a slightly paler grayish bloom. There were times when these dark feathers of the upperwing seemed to be glossed purplish or bluish. Eventually, we saw the bird directly overhead at close range and could see small yellowish to pinkish-yellow feet, a dark gray bill with a pale gray to blue gray cere. The eyes were dark red. The underwing pattern was distinctive in being snowy white across the wing linings (lesser, median, and greater coverts of underwing). The rest of the wing, the remiges, were black, as was the entire tail.  The bird played on the wind as it hunted flying insects. The kite sometimes made rapid banks and turns to zero in on prey. I could not actually see any of the prey, but when the bird grabbed something (apparently) it reached forward with its feet and met them with its beak. It appeared to consume its prey on the wing. As photos show, these were small flying insects (not dragonflies or damselflies as far as I could tell). The bird seemed to find most of its prey over the tops of the trees, but occasionally much higher.  After meeting some locals, I learned that the bird had been seen by them since about September 7 (a rainy day that coincided with the remnants of hurricane Dorian passing east of here into Nova Scotia). This may be coincidence given other recent northerly Swallow-tailed Kites well away from the storms influence.

Locality: stakeout Swallow-tailed Kite, Caves Rd., Howard (2019)
Observation Details: Continuing sleek, black-and-white raptor with forked tail. Many photos to come.

Locality: 1924 Joe Kennedy Rd NE, Glennville US-GA 31.90270, -81.86555

Observation Details: Continuing here. Gorgeous first year bird, first seen circling with a vulture on the right side of the road as I first pulled up. It soon descended and crossed over to the left side of the road to begin foraging over the field; eventually crossed back over to its favored tree across from the farm sign. Preened a bit and then took off to forage again, this time giving fantastic views! I left after it landed again. Just an incredible bird and what a mastery of flight. Curious drivers who stopped to ask what we were looking at were not disappointed!

I initially observed this bird perched on the tall Pines bordering the park on the east side. It also briefly perched on an adjacent large tower. The bird briefly disappeared behind the pines then flew back out flying over my head then down into the park where it landed in a sycamore. The bird then flew from the sycamores into the pines in the adjacent neighborhood on the west side of the park. We observed it drop down onto the grass and catch what appeared to be a mole or gopher, and then flew into an adjacent Pine where we watched it eat the rodent over the course of 20 to 30 minutes before flying back down into the park and disappearing.  This was an overall small Bueto that was fairly similar in size to a Red-shouldered Hawk, maybe slightly smaller. The head was overall fairly round, with a darkish cap and dark “mustache”, as well as a whitish throat. The bird also had a brownish eye, and mostly yellow bill with a dark hooked tip. The breast was an overall mottled reddish brown color with a white base, with mottling becoming more sparse as well as more barred towards the belly and flanks, giving way to a mostly white belly and vent. The wings and back were an overall medium brown color with most feathers becoming paler towards the edges. In flight the bird had a very dark almost black border on the wings extending from the primaries down through the trailing edge of the wing all the way to the tail. We remarked that this edging was somewhat reminiscent of a Gray Hawk. The underwing was overall lightly patterned, with light brownish mottling becoming lighter and more barred towards the trailing edge of the wing. The tail feathers were also strikingly marked with black and white bands.

Locality: 12606 Prima Vista Dr, San Antonio US-TX (29.5555,-98.3976)
Media notes: potential first county nest record
Observation Details: close to local sunset, finally observed two adult BWHAs sitting together in their favored perch -- when I returned with my camera, I arrived just in time to observe one adult fly across the street into mid-crown of a tree across the street -- I had seen this nest before when searching for stick nest structures but could never determine if a bird was incubating -- as far as I can tell, only one chick in the nest -- unsure at first but San Antonio Audubon folks voted to confirm this record as the first documented nest record for Bexar County
Adult

Locality: Colorado State Univ. Environmental Learning Center

Observation Details: I was driving roads south of the Cedar Rapids Airport en route to pick up a friend at the airport around 1:15 PM.  While driving along Linn Johnson Rd NW I happened to see a stand of white pine on a farmstead on the south side of the road (Johnson Co.) with a large accipiter perched out in the wide open.  Luckily, I had been birding earlier and I had my camera with me.  As I approached the bird nothing in my mind/searching pattern was triggered i.e. I knew it was too big to be a Cooper's Hawk.  I was able to photograph the juvenile bird.  It was very white and appeared rather long in length (from head to tail) on approach.  Photos revealed very large wings like a buteo, a white supercilium, the outer wings have rufous coloration/speckling, the tail-bands are uneven (with the light bands being thicker than the dark ones and also with some thin white edging between the light and dark bands, but not apparent on the last couple terminating bands), and pale bars were located on the greater coverts.  As it flew away from me it tore back into the property into some thicker foliage.  I noticed the base of its tail was much broader than a Cooper's Hawk, even without binoculars.  Photos were confirmed by JF in the field as I coincidentally ran into him later that day.

Locality: Colorado State Univ. Environmental Learning Center

P

**RARE | Continuing bird first seen yesterday, 29 September 2016. I first found this bird in the northern  part of the airport sitting on the Medway Road fence line around 1350. The bird stayed on the airport side of Medway Road throughout the time I was there. When I left around 1615, the bird had moved closer to the airport offices, and was foraging out in the fields of the runway area.  Behavior: Would perch on fence or on ground. Hunted for most of the time I was there, successfully catching insects, typically grasshoppers, and other unidentified prey. Often would run on the ground, as well as flying down from a perch on the fence to capture prey. At one point the bird took off circled a few times gaining elevation, and plummeted in a dive. On 4 or 5 occasions, the bird would fly up to the fence directly in front of us, and allow for fantastic opportunities to study this bird up close. There no reason to approach rare birds beyond a respectable point, but this bird would fly in to distances that were much closer than I feel comfortable getting to a rare bird. It was an amazing experience with a stunning bird.
Very wet, hanging out on posts

Immediately found running along the fence beside the airport road, then perched on the fence. A fairly large immature buteo with small light colored head, streaked breast and back, long wings with light edges to flight feathers; Buffy throat and around the eye area; yellow cere and legs; First reported on Sept 29 and documented by many others on September 30th, seen running along the ground and foraging in the grass catching bugs, presumably grasshoppers. We were alone when we first arrived, but we're soon joined by 6 other birders and several local curious people wondering what the scopes and cameras were all about; photos to come

Locality: Heart of the Hills Fisheries Ctr. (Sign in at office)(HOTW 069)

Media notes: shot holding my camera out the driver's side window
Observation Details: initially, from a distance, I thought this was a Crow.  It was being harassed by a Red-tailed Hawk.  As I came closer, it was obviously not a Crow, but a rather unusual raptor for this area.
Continuing bird.   Will attach photos.  Flying over ponds next to, but outside of zoo.

Medium size hawk mostly black with yellow cere and legs. Wings have narrow bars on both primaries and secondaries.  I was able to visualize three wide white bands on the adult’s tail when it was spread. Bands on the immature bird were numerous and narrow and it had several white feathers visible on it’s breast.
Could not see into the nest. Both birds were agitated and I did not linger

Media notes: Adult
Observation Details: Medium size hawk mostly black with yellow cere and legs. Wings have narrow bars on both primaries and secondaries.  I was able to visualize three wide white bands on the adult’s tail when it was spread. Bands on the immature bird were numerous and narrow and it had several white feathers visible on it's breast.
There were several new immature birds along with the usual four birds that have been here for some time.
Adults, seen eating a large fish, chased off by a Red-winged Blackbird, photos
2 adults

Locality: Mt Carmel Junction Roadkill Pileup Spot
Observation Details: Feeding on a dead mule deer which had been hit by a car and moved off the road
A pair were maintaining a nest. One caught a fish in one of the ponds and carried it to the nest.
*rare - banded birds viewed perched and in flight at close range; photos

Locality: Buena Vista Dr.--b/w Old Port Dr./CR350 & Ocean Blvd./CR100
Observation Details: Great looks. Flew over my head and landed on pole directly behind me. Very lucky.

Lifer!  One bird spotted perched in a tree a few hundred meters from nest, flew in to the nest box to give some decent scope views but no photos before entering the box and transforming into a small, unidentifiable lump inside the box. After maybe fifteen minutes of waiting, the bird didn't reemerge, so we resigned ourselves to the views, and left. A hundred meters down the road, spotted up a raptor on the fence by the highway, slammed on the brakes ... Aplomado at point-blank range. Sat and preened for about 15 minutes, giving absolutely ridiculous looks. Probably the closest I've been to any wild falcon, nevermind an aplomado

Locality: Old Port Isabel Rd, Brownsville US-TX 25.98904, -97.43766
Observation Details: South side of road about 1/2 mile apart. One perched on telephone pole  at by 10:00 across from the yellow back gate of RV park. The other seen at 9:45 south of the lake on west side of the road. Flushed from ground with quarry as we drove by. Intense breakfast eating looks for this lifer! Will report this banded bird.
Three clear birds. One seen far away.

Banded bird on telephone pole eating male Painted Bunting. Flew to tree branch and spread tail. It;s a large falcon with a very long thin tail. Gray crown, white eyebrow, dark malar stripe, white breast, orange "leggings" and vent with bright yellow legs and cere.

Locality: 27853–27909 Buena Vista Blvd, Los Fresnos US-TX (26.1592,-97.3595)

Media notes: SY bird, immature plumage but to call her immature is vague, she is building a nest today

Locality: Walden Ponds Wildlife Habitat--Walden & Sawhill Ponds all together
Media notes: Cooper's Hawk, Walden/Sawhill complex.
Observation Details: A wet juvenile at the Sawhill/Walden boundary.

Caught a MODO and was mantling on the side of the road. Motionless for about ten minutes, not even flushing as cars drove by feet away; was probably focused squeezing the life out of it. Eventually looked down at the dove, decided it was dead enough for its liking, and flew off

1 adult and 1 juvenile

Locality: Mustang Island State Park, Corpus Christi US-TX (27.6928,-97.1633)

Media notes: A front view of a juvenile White-tailed Hawk in a palm. Elevation: 39 m. Date added to IBC: June 22, 2016.

Locality: Santa Ana NWR--Entry and Parking lot

Observation Details: Ferruginous Hawk captures Prairie Dog, begins to share it with 4 of its presumed kin, then Golden Eagle blasts in and takes the meal from the group.  The Ferruginous scatter and watch the Eagle savor the spoils.. from a safe distance.
Photo, continuing
